description.narrative:
FNV Metal is strongly represented in various works councils and employee representatives of companies in the Metal and Technology sector, also known as small metal. FNV Metaal concludes collective agreements in the Metal Technology sector for industries and companies. This states which employment conditions - such as wages, working hours and the like - apply in the coming period. In addition,FNV argues for more sustainability in the metal chains, also with regard to workers in countries where metal or scrap material is #sourced. FNV cooperates with partner trade unions worldwide to improve compliance with the labor rights of workers in this sector. Labor rights violations, such as unhealthy or unsafe working conditions, low wages and lack of access tosocial security - in the metal-mining industry or in the work of scrap metal collectors - regularly come to the fore here.
As part of the process, the FNV and other civil society organizations are negotiating with the VNMI branch organization about mechanisms to, among other things, eliminate labor rights violations in the metal chain, with regard to heavy industry and the recycling of scrap or artisanal mining.
FNV wants to get the branch organization present to carry out due diligence throughout the entire metal chain and to commit to compliance with the OECD guidelines for multinational companies. FNV works together with CNV, UNICEF and IUCN. Through its membership of IndustriALL, FNV has gained experience in coal mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Columbia in recent years. Via IndustriALL Global and Mondiaal FNV, FNV has a wide network of partner unions in countries where sourcing is taking place.

participating-org.narrative:
The FNV is the largest trade union confederation in the Netherlands. It was formed through the merging in 1976 of the Netherlands Federation of Trade Unions (NVV) and the Catholic Federation of Dutch Trade Unions (NKV), the formal process being completedin 1982.
As early as the 1960s, it had been realized that a more firmly knit bond between the then three existing confederations (NVV, NKV and CNV, the Christian Trade Union Federation) was necessary for the purposes of united negotiations at industrylevel and sometimes at enterprise level. The ultimate formation of one united confederation proved difficult, however, among other things because the existing three were still too closely linked to other organizations (political parties) of the same (denominational) character, plus the fact that their mutual ideological differences were still very great. In the event, the NVV and NKV merged to form the new FNV confederation, while the CNV continued as a separate one. There are 18 unions affiliated to theFNV, with over a million members in all.Its membership likewise stood at just over a million in 1980, but then dropped over the following ten years to around 900,000; after 1990 it rose to just over the million mark once again.
